repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Second Social
            Sector Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Social Sector Adjustment
            Credit Project (SOSAC II) was approved by IDA on June 15,
            2004. It was never declared effective because the reform
            program in Bosnia and Herzegovina (FBH) (affecting two
            thirds of the loan) was not fully implemented in the
            aftermath of the Board approval. Once it became clear that
            the efforts to restructure the operation in late 2005/ early
            2006 would not succeed, SOSAC II was allowed to expire at
            the end of June 2006 after the extended effectiveness
            deadline was not met. SOSAC II had a troubled history almost
            from the very beginning. The operation was originally
            negotiated in 2002. However, the Government authorities
            failed to sign the Minutes of Negotiations and the project
            could not be presented to the Board in June 2002. The
            Minutes of Negotiation were signed in April 2004 and the
            operation was presented to and approved by the Board in June
            2004. However, there was further delay because the operation
            failed to get ratified by the Parliament of FBH. Final
            efforts to reinvigorate the process to enable the operation
            to be declared effective did not succeed as the Bank and the
            Government could not reach agreement on the medium-term
            expenditure framework for social assistance.

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Second Social
            Sector Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Social
            Sector Adjustment Credit (SOSAC II) is to support reforms in
            cash transfer and labor programs and institutions in
            Bosnia-Herzegovina--which reorient social protection towards
            programs that protect the poorest and most disabled in a
            fiscally sustainable manner. This is consistent with broader
            efforts to reduce public spending and focus it on priority
            needs, and to address regional imbalances within each
            Entity. These objectives are key elements of the recently
            approved Medium Term Development Strategy (PRSP).
            Specifically, the priority program goals are to: (1) ensure
            that protection for disabled veterans and survivor families
            is better focused on the most disabled, while gradually
            reducing public spending on veterans' programs; (2)
            improve the impact and efficiency of the social safety net
            for the poorest, in particular social welfare benefits and
            services, including a strengthened role for the
            non-government sector; (3) consolidate an appropriate
            institutional structure for employment services at State and
            Entity levels, and reorient active labor policies to
            increase cost effectiveness, transparency and employment
            outcomes; (iv) improve the efficiency and equity of pension
            and disability programs, including pensions policy
            harmonization between the Entities of BH; and (v) ensure
            that social policy reforms are done on the basis of better
            information, within the system and to the public, and that
            living standards monitoring is  more effective and timely.
